panels.visual: In a shadowed corridor at night, young Iksha transforms herself. She binds her hair beneath a cap, charcoal darkening her eyebrows. Her fine silk garments have been exchanged for a young prince's simple training clothes. Her eyes gleam with determination in the candlelight.
panels.dialogue: Bansi.Young: "I'll go for you. To your lessons. You can sleep, practice archery, whatever you want."

panels.visual: Prince Vikrahma stares at his sister in disbelief. He is small for his age, with a sulky expression. Behind him, his chambers show evidence of avoided responsibilities - practice scrolls untouched, training weapons gathering dust.
panels.dialogue: Vikrahma: "What? You... you could do that?"

panels.visual: Iksha sits among the princes in the lesson hall, head bowed appropriately, dressed as Vikrahma. The tutor speaks passionately about ancient battles and the constellations of the stars. Her eyes are bright with the knowledge she is drinking in - warfare, strategy, the movements of the heavens.
panels.narration: She learned to answer when called upon but not so brilliantly as to draw attention. To be unremarkable in a room full of princes.

panels.visual: Split panel showing contrast: on one side, Vikrahma sleeps peacefully in a garden. On the other, Iksha-as-Vikrahma absorbs a lesson on mathematics, her fingers tracing equations in the air. Knowledge consumed like a desert drinks rain.
panels.narration: She learned the world was larger than the palace walls, and she was meant for more than embroidery and arranged marriage.
